    Design of Conformationally Constrained Acyl Sulfonamide Isosteres: Identification of N-([1,2,4]Triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methane-sulfonamides as Potent and Selective hNaV1.7 Inhibitors for the Treatment of Pain

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The sodium channel NaV1.7 has emerged as a promising target for the treatment of pain based on strong genetic validation of its role in nociception. In recent years, a number of aryl and acyl sulfonamides have been reported as potent inhibitors of NaV1.7, with high selectivity over the cardiac isoform NaV1.5. Herein, we report on the discovery of a novel series of N-([1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamides as selective NaV1.7 inhibitors. Starting with the crystal structure of an acyl sulfonamide, we rationalized that cyclization to form a fused heterocycle would improve physicochemical properties, in particular lipophilicity. Our design strategy focused on optimization of potency for block of NaV1.7 and human metabolic stability. Lead compounds 10, 13 (GNE-131), and 25 showed excellent potency, good in vitro metabolic stability, and low in vivo clearance in mouse, rat, and dog. Compound 13 also displayed excellent efficacy in a transgenic mouse model of induced pain.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Voltage-gated sodium channels are transmembrane ion channels involved in many important physiological processes. Nine isoforms are known in mammals (NaV1.1 to NaV1.9), with different expression patterns in muscle, the central (CNS) and peripheral nervous systems (PNS), and neuroendocrine cells.(1) Three isoforms are expressed primarily in nociceptors and mediate pain signaling and amplification in humans (NaV1.7, 1.8, and 1.9). In particular, there is strong genetic evidence supporting the crucial role of NaV1.7 and its encoding SCN9A gene in pain sensation. Gain-of-function mutations in the SCN9A gene lead to painful human disorders, including inherited erythromelalgia (IEM), paroxysmal extreme pain disorder (PEPD), and idiopathic small fiber neuropathies.(2) In contrast, congenital insensitivity to pain (CIP), a rare disorder characterized by a complete loss of the ability to sense painful stimuli, was found to be caused by loss-of-function mutations in the SCN9A gene.(3) Notably, SCN9A loss-of-function mutations have little or no effect on motor, cognitive, or non-nociceptive sensory function. These findings suggest that selective NaV1.7 antagonism may be a highly effective strategy to develop novel analgesics with minimal side effects and have made NaV1.7 a promising target for the treatment of pain. Indeed, there is considerable interest in developing small molecule NaV1.7 inhibitors as analgesics, and progress has been covered in several excellent reviews.(4) However, non-isoform-selective sodium channel block may lead to undesirable side effects. In particular, inhibition of the cardiac sodium channel, NaV1.5, is of concern due to the potential for arrhythmia, which would limit the therapeutic potential. Loss of function mutations in the SCN5A gene encoding NaV1.5 lead to Brugada Syndrome or LenÃ¨greâs disease, a slowly developing myocardial conduction defect.(5)
    Isoform-selective NaV1.7 inhibitors have attracted considerable interest in recent years due to their potential to avoid nonselective block of sodium channels and thus to provide an improved therapeutic index. Two distinct series of isoform-selective NaV1.7 inhibitors have been reported. Initial reports described heteroaryl sulfonamides containing an acidic sulfonamide that showed high selectivity for NaV1.7 over NaV1.5.(6) This series was shown to bind to a unique site in the voltage sensor domain 4 (VSD4) of NaV1.7 by elegant mutagenesis studies.(7) We were able to confirm the binding mode of aryl sulfonamides and recently disclosed the cocrystal structure of an analog in complex with a chimeric construct consisting of human NaV1.7 VSD4 and a bacterial sodium channel pore domain.(8) Subsequently, a second series of highly isoform-selective NaV1.7 inhibitors was disclosed, characterized by an acidic acyl sulfonamide headgroup (Figure 1).(9,10) The latter series was shown to also occupy the VSD4 binding site based on NaV1.7 radioligand binding data using a tritiated aryl sulfonamide.(9b)
    We have had a long-standing interest in developing small molecule inhibitors of NaV1.7 for the treatment of pain(11) and initially explored the aryl sulfonamide scaffold in search of a lead series for further development. Although we identified potent and highly selective NaV1.7 blockers and discovered a tool compound that demonstrated significant in vivo efficacy in preclinical proof-of-concept studies, this series of compounds lacked adequate oral bioavailability.(6a,b) We next pursued acyl sulfonamides, since this class of NaV1.7 inhibitors occupies a different physicochemical property space compared to aryl sulfonamides, in particular with respect to molecular weight and lipophilicity. We identified compound 1 as a lead, a highly potent and novel acyl sulfonamide with good selectivity over NaV1.5, albeit only poor stability in human liver microsomes (Figure 1).(10) Furthermore, acyl sulfonamide 1 required high plasma exposure (>30 Î¼M) to show efficacy in an induced-pain model using transgenic FVB mice. Compound 1 displays a high fraction of sp3 hybridized carbons (Fsp3), a rather unique feature among other acyl sulfonamide scaffolds (Figure 1), which is considered beneficial for successful clinical development.(12)
    In parallel to the optimization of acyl sulfonamides exemplified by 1, we were looking for alternative acidic head groups to mitigate any potential issues arising from the acyl sulfonamide moiety. In addition, we sought to improve potency and metabolic stability and optimize the physicochemical properties of the molecules. In particular, we were interested in compounds with a lower lipophilicity (cLogP < 3) and improved lipophilic efficiency (LipE), as they are generally thought to improve drug-like properties and safety.(14)
    An opportunity to achieve these goals became apparent from a small molecule crystal structure of compound 1 (Figure 2). Analysis of the crystal structure revealed that the carbonyl oxygen and the aryl fluoride adopt a syn-orientation (Figure 2A). The carbonyl oxygen is rotated out of plane with a measured 38Â° dihedral angle relative to the C15âC16 bond. Energy calculations revealed that the molecule possessed a low energy barrier to rotation with respect to the C15âC16 bond (see Supporting Information, Figure S1). We reasoned that the small molecule crystal structure conformation might resemble the bioactive conformation of the molecule. It was hypothesized that reinforcing this conformation with an appropriate cyclic constraint would be tolerated and thus provide conformationally rigidified isosteres of acyl sulfonamides.(16) We envisioned that replacing the aryl fluoride and carbonyl group of acyl sulfonamide 1 by a fused five membered heterocycle would be suitable to test our hypothesis. It was anticipated that this approach would allow retaining the acidic nature of the headgroup and maintaining key pharmacophore features, such as hydrogen bond acceptors (see Supporting Information, Figure S2), while also potentially reducing lipophilicity. To this end, we calculated pKa and LogP of a range of fused, bicyclic aromatic systems that we considered as acyl sulfonamide replacements (Table 1). Compared with the acyl sulfonamide group (core A), a benzo[d]isoxazole (core B) and [1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridine (core F) appeared most attractive in terms of cpKa or cLogP, and were therefore selected for synthesis. Despite acceptable calculated properties, indazole core D was initially not considered for synthesis as the additional hydrogen bond donor was thought to not match the pharmacophore requirements (see Supporting Information, Figure S2).
    Table 1. Calculated Parameters of Acyl Sulfonamide and Selected Heterocyclic Cores
    a

    cpKa and cLogP were calculated using MoKa, version 2.6.5.(13)

    As a consequence of rigidifying 1, the heteroatoms of the five membered heterocycles are now coplanar with the central phenyl ring, whereas the carbonyl oxygen of 1 that they are replacing is rotated out of plane by 38Â° (Figure 2B). We expected that despite this difference in the placement of a potential hydrogen bond acceptor, the cyclic constraint might be able to maintain key interactions with the protein.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Benzisoxazole 4, triazole 5, and acyl sulfonamide 1 were tested for activity in a human NaV1.7 radioligand-binding assay (LBA) measuring the displacement of tritiated aryl sulfonamide [3H]GX-545.(8) A strong correlation was previously observed for functional channel inhibition and [3H]GX-545 radioligand binding,(8) so we used the LBA as our primary screening assay. Functional activity of selected analogs was evaluated by automated voltage-clamp on a PatchXpress (PX) platform, measuring the inhibition of sodium currents mediated by human NaV1.7 channels expressed in HEK293 cells.
    Benzisoxazole 4 showed a 14-fold drop in potency compared to its acyl sulfonamide counterpart 1 (Table 2). Gratifyingly, triazole 5 was only 3-fold less potent than 1, supporting our initial hypothesis. Furthermore, while 5 displayed comparable lipophilicity to 1, improved metabolic stability was seen. Measured pKa values showed that, while 5 displayed an increased acidic pKa relative to 1 (pKa 5.6 vs 3.8), it would remain fully ionized at physiological pH 7.4. Based on these promising results, we decided to further explore the triazole sulfonamide scaffold represented by compound 5.
    Table 2. Potencies of Constrained Heterocyclic Acyl Sulfonamides
    a

    Human NaV1.7 radioligand binding assay (LBA); IC50 for displacement of [3H]GX-545, reported as mean value Â± SD from at least two independent determinations.

    b

    LogD measured at pH 7.4 (n = 1).

    c

    cLogP and cpKa were calculated using MoKa, version 2.6.5.(13)

    d

    Measured using an UV-metric method.(17)

    e

    Calculated from NaV1.7 LBA IC50 and measured LogD.

    f

    Predicted hepatic clearance extrapolated from in vitro human liver microsome (HLM) experiments; SD not applicable.

    Optimization of the triazole series focused on improving LipE and probing SAR relative to the corresponding acyl sulfonamides. In particular, we were interested in further validating our hypothesis that triazoles, as constrained acyl sulfonamides, would present a similar binding mode and as a result display similar SAR. We therefore applied SAR knowledge from the optimization of the acyl sulfonamide series to generate matched molecular pairs. We included compounds that would not necessarily be considered beneficial in terms of lead optimization but were useful to compare SAR between the two series. Selected examples of triazole SAR are shown in Tables 3 and 4.
    Table 3. Adamantyl Triazole SAR
    compdR1R2NaV1.7 LBA IC50a (Î¼M)LogD7.4bLipEcHLM Clhepd (mL/min/kg)
    5ClMe0.20Â Â±Â 0.052.74.012
    6HMe3.88Â Â±Â 0.512.23.212
    7BrMe0.16Â Â±Â 0.062.84.013
    8EtMe0.17Â Â±Â 0.033.13.716
    9i-PrMe0.14Â Â±Â 0.022.94.017
    10cPrMe0.01Â Â±Â 0.003.54.514
    11cBuMe0.02Â Â±Â 0.013.93.812
    12cPrCHF20.12Â Â±Â 0.013.13.818
    13cPrcPr0.01Â Â±Â 0.013.84.112
    14cPrcBu0.01Â Â±Â 0.004.73.212
    15cPrNHMe0.05Â Â±Â 0.003.24.112
    a

    Human NaV1.7 radioligand binding assay (LBA); IC50 for displacement of [3H]GX-545, reported as mean value Â± SD from at least two independent determinations.

    b

    LogD measured at pH 7.4 (n = 1).

    c

    Calculated from NaV1.7 LBA IC50 and measured LogD.

    d

    Predicted hepatic clearance extrapolated from in vitro human liver microsome (HLM) experiments; SD not applicable.

    Table 4. SAR of Cycloalkyl Ether Group
    a

    Human NaV1.7 radioligand binding assay (LBA); IC50 for displacement of [3H]GX-545, reported as mean value Â± SD from at least two independent determinations.

    b

    LogD measured at pH 7.4 (n = 1).

    c

    Calculated from NaV1.7 LBA IC50 and measured LogD.

    d

    Predicted hepatic clearance extrapolated from in vitro human liver microsome (HLM) experiments; SD not applicable.

    Based on prior experience, we began by exploring modifications of the R1 substituent on the triazole core (Table 3). The size and nature of this substituent proved to be crucial for improving potency.
    The replacement of chlorine at R1 (5) with bromine (7) or aliphatic groups such as ethyl (8) and isopropyl (9) was tolerated, without affecting potency against NaV1.7. In contrast, removal of the R1 substituent altogether (compound 6) led to a 19-fold drop in potency, highlighting the importance of this substituent. Notably, the R1 substituent also affected the metabolic stability. In particular, introduction of aliphatic substituents led to a decrease in HLM (human liver microsome) stability (compound 8 vs 5).
    Consistent with data from our acyl sulfonamide series,(10) employing a cyclopropyl group at R1 provided a marked improvement in potency. In this case, changing an isopropyl (compound 9) to a cyclopropyl group (compound 10) led to a 14-fold boost in potency and slightly better HLM stability. Functional activity of 10 against human NaV1.7 was assessed by voltage-clamp to give an IC50 of 0.003 Â± 0.002 Î¼M (mean Â± SD).
    Increasing the ring size was tolerated, with cyclobutyl analog 11 maintaining potency relative to cyclopropyl triazole 10, although LipE was decreased. The excellent potency of 10 and its superior LipE compared to cyclobutyl 11 prompted us to use the cyclopropyl group at R1 for further SAR studies. Next, we probed analogs of methyl sulfonamide for their effect on NaV1.7 inhibition and HLM stability. Addition of fluorine atoms to the methyl sulfonamide moiety of 10 to give compound 12 was not tolerated, leading to a 12-fold drop in potency. Conversely, replacement of the methyl group at R2 with bigger groups such as cyclopropyl (compound 13) or cyclobutyl (compound 14) was tolerated and potency was maintained relative to 10. Lipophilicity increased, in particular for 14, resulting in an erosion of LipE. Compound 13 showed moderate clearance in human liver microsomes and excellent functional activity against human NaV1.7 with an IC50 of 0.003 Â± 0.001 Î¼M.
    In addition to C-linked groups at R2, we also probed a few N-linked analogs such methylamine 15, which was 5-fold less potent than methyl sulfonamide 10. Despite reduced lipophilicity, 15 did not show better metabolic stability over more lipophilic analogs such as 14.
    We suspected that oxidation of the adamantane moiety was a major metabolic clearance pathway as previously observed.(18) Our strategy to reduce metabolism focused on commonly used approaches, such as reducing lipophilicity or increasing steric bulk to reduce recognition by CYP enzymes. In addition, we expected that either removing or blocking metabolically labile sites on the lipophilic appendage by fluorine substituents would improve HLM stability. Therefore, with the optimal groups identified for R1 (cyclopropyl) and R2 (methyl or cyclopropyl), we then explored SAR of the substituent at the ether linkage, R3. Representative examples summarizing our efforts are shown in Table 4. Eliminating a methylene between the triazole core and the adamantane reduced lipophilicity but also resulted in a steep drop in potency (compound 16, 118-fold compared to 10). In contrast, extending the linker by one methylene group (compound 17) had no impact on the potency against NaV1.7. However, the extended linker led to a considerable drop in metabolic stability. We explored several different aliphatic appendages as adamantane replacements, exemplified by cyclohexane 18 and 6,6-dimethylbicyclo[3.1.1]heptane 19. Compound 18 markedly improved LipE, despite an 11-fold drop in LBA potency. The potency loss of 18 relative to 10 was confirmed by voltage clamp, and a human NaV1.7 IC50 of 0.014 Î¼M Â± 0.002 Î¼M was measured for compound 18. Most notably, the reduced lipophilicity of 18 also provided excellent HLM stability. Other aliphatic appendages such 6,6-dimethylbicyclo[3.1.1]heptane (compound 19), an attempt to increase steric bulk, often showed excellent potency combined with comparable or improved LipE relative to 10, but generally poor HLM stability. Metabolic stability could be improved by introducing fluorine substituents on the aliphatic appendage, although at the expense of lower potency against NaV1.7. An example is 1-fluorobicyclo[2.2.2]octane 20, which was 16-fold less potent compared to 10 but considerably more stable in HLM.
    At this point, we considered triazole 13 to be the most promising lead, as it showed the best combination of high potency against NaV1.7, higher LipE, and increased stability in human liver microsomes compared to other adamantyl and cycloalkyl triazoles. Analogs such as 18 and 20 substantially improved HLM stability. However, the potency against NaV1.7 for these highly plasma protein bound acids (vide infra) was considered to be insufficient to provide in vivo efficacy at low plasma concentrations based on our experience with related acyl sulfonamides.
    In our search for highly potent, metabolically stable triazoles, we next turned our attention to aromatic replacements of the adamantane moiety(19) since this would allow us to probe a different chemical space compared to cycloalkyl groups (Table 5). As a consequence of this strategy, Fsp3 would be reduced, and we were cognizant of the potential impact on the properties of the resultant compounds.(12) Initial studies were conducted using an isoxazole core for ease of synthesis. Replacing the adamantane in isoxazole 4 with 3,4-dichlorophenyl provided 21, which retained the weak NaV1.7 potency of 4. More importantly, 21 displayed excellent HLM stability and low lipophilicity. Encouraged by these results, we searched for opportunities to improve the potency against NaV1.7. Interestingly, inverting the oxymethylene linker in 21 to give its isomer 22 provided an 8-fold boost in potency. A similar difference in potency was observed when these compounds were tested for inhibition of NaV1.7 in a voltage-clamp assay (Figure 3A). We hypothesized that the torsion angle preference of the linker affects the conformation of the compounds and inhibition of NaV1.7. Small molecule conformational preferences derived from analysis of data from the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) and Protein Data Bank (PDB),(20) and global energy minimization of 21 and 22 using OMEGA(21a,b) and SZYBKI(21c) (Figure 3B) supported our rationale. Thus, aryl methylene groups, such as the benzisoxazole core in 22, preferentially adopt a perpendicular orientation (90Â° torsion angle), allowing the linker to orient the phenyl and the benzisoxazole ring into an optimal geometry for binding. In contrast, an alkoxy aryl linker as in 21 prefers a planar orientation (0Â° torsion angle).
    Table 5. Aryl Isoxazole and Triazole SAR
    a

    Human NaV1.7 radioligand binding assay (LBA); IC50 for displacement of [3H]GX-545, reported as mean value Â± SD from at least two independent determinations.

    b

    LogD measured at pH 7.4 (n = 1).

    c

    Calculated from NaV1.7 LBA IC50 and measured LogD.

    d

    Predicted hepatic clearance extrapolated from in vitro human liver microsome (HLM) experiments; SD not applicable.

    Consistent with previous observations, replacing the chlorine at R1 by cyclopropyl to give 23 further improved potency and LipE (Table 5). The high potency in ligand binding was confirmed by voltage-clamp assay on human NaV1.7, with a measured IC50 of 0.002 Â± 0.001 Î¼M. In addition, 23 demonstrated low clearance in human liver microsomes. We next replaced the isoxazole with the triazole core, as initial data shown in Table 2 suggested that this core would provide compounds with improved lipophilicity. Indeed, replacing the isoxazole core of 23 with a triazole was tolerated and provided a considerable reduction in lipophilicity. Triazole 24 retained potency and metabolic stability of 23, while increasing LipE. Finally, changing the 3,4-dichlorophenyl group to a 3,5-dichlorophenyl group provided compound 25, which combined high potency against NaV1.7 (voltage-clamp IC50 of 0.001 Â± 0.001 Î¼M) with excellent HLM stability and with low lipophilicity.
    In general, SAR trends observed in the acyl sulfonamide series were reflected in the triazole series. For instance, a cyclopropyl group at R1 led to a marked improvement in potency in both series compared to other substituents. In comparison to their acyl sulfonamide counterparts, most triazole sulfonamides displayed lower ligand binding affinity (Figure 4A), with decreases from 2- to 28-fold observed. Notable exceptions included compounds 10, 24, and 25, for which the LBA potency was within 1â2 fold of the corresponding acyl sulfonamide analog. On the other hand, triazole sulfonamides typically showed better stability in HLM compared to acyl sulfonamides (Figure 4B), which may compensate for their reduced potency. As examples, 10, 13, and 25 were 1.5â2-fold more stable than the corresponding acyl sulfonamides (10, 14 vs 19 mL/min/kg; 13, 12 vs 18 mL/min/kg; 25, 3.9 vs 9.5 mL/min/kg).
    It should be noted that measured pKa values indicated an increased acidic pKa for triazoles with aliphatic substituents at R1 compared to chloro substituted triazole 5. As such, we measured pKa values of 6.7 for 10 and 13. Therefore, a small fraction of these compounds will remain nonionized at physiological pH 7.4, which will likely affect LogD values and possibly potency relative to the acyl sulfonamides that will be fully ionized at this pH.
    In addition to possible pKa effects, we rationalized that the observed shift in potency between acyl and triazole sulfonamides (Figure 4) may be a consequence of a conformational constraint that negatively affects potential hydrogen bond donor/acceptor interactions of triazoles within the binding site versus the more flexible acyl sulfonamides. Although the latter bind to the same VSD4 site of NaV1.7 as aryl sulfonamides, little is known about the precise binding mode of acyl sulfonamides.(9b) To gain further understanding of the binding modes of acyl and triazole sulfonamides, we conducted site directed mutagenesis of specific residues within the anion binding pocket of the VSD4 site. Three arginine residue mutations within the anion binding pocket were generated (R1602A, R1605A, and R1608A), as well as a mutation of the tyrosine side chain (Y1537A) that forms the floor of the binding pocket (Figure 5C).(8)
    Similar to aryl sulfonamides,(8) NaV1.7 inhibition potency for triazole and acyl sulfonamides is dominated by R1608. Thus, the R1608A mutation eradicated potency for all compounds tested (Figure 5A,B). Mutations of R1602 and R1605 had little impact on binding of aryl sulfonamides to VSD4 (up to 6-fold reduction in potency).(8) In contrast, the two arginine residues contributed substantially to binding of both acyl and triazole sulfonamides. Potency for chloro-substituted adamantane ethers 1 and 5 was reduced to a similar extent by replacement of either R1602 or R1605 by alanine, resulting in a >300-fold reduction.
    The mutagenesis data show notable similarities between acyl and triazole sulfonamide binding, thus supporting a similar binding mode between the two series. Nonetheless, differences in binding for acyl and triazole sulfonamides were also revealed. For instance, inhibitory potency for triazole 10 was impacted to a greater extent by R1602 and R1605 mutations in comparison to its acyl sulfonamide counterpart (see Supporting Information).
    Selected analogs were further profiled against multiple human sodium channel isoforms (NaV1.1, 1.2, 1.5, 1.6, and 1.7) using the PatchXpress automated voltage-clamp system (Table 6). In general, the triazoles reported herein displayed high selectivity against the cardiac sodium channel NaV1.5, from 37-fold selectivity for 13 to >1300-fold for 25. Lower isoform selectivity was observed against other sodium channels, in particular NaV1.2. Thus, while the triazoles showed 15- to >110-fold and 13- to 16-fold selectivity for NaV1.7 over NaV1.1 and NaV1.6, respectively, the selectivity for NaV1.7 over NaV1.2 was only 2â10-fold. Potency measurements on the Qube automated voltage-clamp platform provided 2â4-fold lower human NaV1.7 IC50 values compared to the PatchXpress system.
    Table 6. Voltage-Clamp IC50 Values for the Inhibition of Human NaV1.x Isoforms
    compdNaV1.1a,b (Î¼M)NaV1.2a,b (Î¼M)NaV1.5a,b (Î¼M)NaV1.6b,c (Î¼M)NaV1.7 PXa,b/Qubeb,c (Î¼M)

    d

    Compounds 13 and 25 were also evaluated for their effects on mouse NaV1.7 using the Qube automated electrophysiology platform, and IC50 values of 0.007 Î¼M (13) and 0.005 Î¼M (25) were measured. Selected analogs were tested in vitro for effects on the hERG potassium channel by automated voltage clamp, and inhibition was generally low (11% Â± 2% inhibition at 10 Î¼M test concentration for compound 13).
    The ADME profile for compounds 10, 13, and 25 is shown in Table 7. All compounds showed moderate to high metabolic stability in liver microsomes, and 13 and 25 also showed high stability in human, rat, and dog hepatocytes. Triazoles 10, 13, and 25 demonstrated moderate permeability in MDR1 transfected MDCK cells, with 25 showing high potential for P-glycoprotein (Pgp) mediated efflux. The compounds showed no appreciable inhibition of CYP isoforms 3A4, 1A2, 2C9, and 2D6, at concentrations of 10 Î¼M. Plasma protein binding (PPB) was determined by rapid equilibrium dialysis and was generally very high (99.0â99.9% in human, mouse, and rat). Testing of 13 and 25 by equilibrium dialysis using HT Dialysis membranes indicated 99.8% and 99.7% PPB in mouse, respectively.
    Table 7. AMDE Profile and Physical Properties for Triazoles 13 and 25

    The pharmacokinetic parameters for 10, 13, and 25 in mice, rats, and dogs after iv administration are shown in Table 8. All compounds show low total clearance (0.8â7 mL/min/kg), consistent with the low in vitro clearance inferred from stability testing with hepatocytes (Table 7). Volume of distribution was low (<0.7 L/kg) and within the range typically observed for acidic compounds.(22)
    Table 8. Pharmacokinetic Parameters for Triazoles 10, 13, and 25 after iv Administrationa
    compdspeciesT1/2 (h)Cl (mL/min/kg)Vss (L/kg)

    a

    Dose: 1 mg/kg for male SpragueâDawley rats (age 9â11 weeks; n = 3) and male CF-1 mice (age 4â5 weeks; n = 3); 0.5 mg/kg for male Beagle dogs (age 6 months to 3 years; n = 3). Data are represented as mean Â± SD.

    We next examined analogs 10, 13, and 25 for target engagement and analgesic activity in vivo. We previously reported on an acute pain and target engagement assay in rats utilizing aconitine, a strong neurotoxin and voltage-gated sodium channel activator.(6b,23) However, rat NaV1.7 VSD4 has marked differences to the human form,(7) and VSD4 binders often show poor potency against rat NaV1.7 that typically requires evaluation of in vivo pharmacology in mice.(6)
    In order to facilitate the in vivo characterization of our compounds, we employed a novel induced-pain model using transgenic FVB mice. In addition to endogenous mouse NaV1.7, these mice express human NaV1.7 with the same gain-of-function mutation (I848T) that causes IEM in humans. The transgenic FVB mice were generated by incorporation of a bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) gene coding for the mutated human sodium channel. A pain response is then induced by injecting aconitine, similar to our rat pain model. Notably, using this study design, aconitine only affects transgenic mice carrying human NaV1.7 but not wild-type mice, and it is therefore felt that inhibition of the pain response represents block of human NaV1.7. We utilized the humanized IEM model throughout the program as the primary assay to evaluate compounds for efficacy and to quantify target engagement of human NaV1.7 in vivo.
    Aconitine was injected into a hindpaw to stimulate the nociceptive response 2 h following oral administration of test compound. Flinching and licking behavior were captured and manually quantified for 30 min post-acontine-injection as nociceptive behavior. At approximately 3 h post-treatment, animals were euthanized and plasma samples were collected. Triazole 10 displayed a dose-dependent reduction of the pain response (Figure 6A), with 31%, 66% and 93% reduction at 3, 10, and 30 mg/kg, relative to the aconitine vehicle. Plasma concentrations (mean Â± SD) were measured as 2.7 Â± 0.6, 12.2 Â± 3.5, and 46.2 Â± 12.5 Î¼M, respectively. Similarly, cyclopropyl sulfonamide analog 13 showed significant reduction of nociceptive behavior at the doses tested, with up to 85% reduction at the 30 mg/kg dose and a plasma concentration of 2.8 Â± 0.8 Î¼M. The EC50 values for the inhibition of nociceptive behavior by the two adamantyl triazoles 10 and 13 were calculated as 5.8 Î¼M (10) and 0.5 Î¼M (13), respectively (Figure 6B).
    In contrast, aryl substituted triazole sulfonamide 25 performed poorly in this induced pain model, with only 32% and 43% reduction of nociceptive behavior following 10 and 30 mg/kg oral administration, respectively. The two doses yielded plasma concentrations of 7.8 Â± 2.6 and 18.8 Â± 8.0 Î¼M, respectively. The EC50 for the inhibition of nociceptive behavior by 25 was estimated as 21.2 Î¼M.
    The poor efficacy of 25 was surprising based on the in vitro profile of the compounds. All three compounds showed similar high potency against human NaV1.7 as measured on the PatchXpress platform. Triazole 25 was the most potent compound based on experiments on the Qube automated voltage-clamp system, while 10 was the least potent compound. Furthermore, all three compounds showed very high plasma protein binding in mice. However, 25 showed only poor efficacy, with >3-fold and >40-fold higher EC50 values for the inhibition of nociceptive behavior compared to 10 and 13, respectively.
    This apparent discrepancy between in vivo efficacy and in vitro potency for different chemotypes is not fully understood, although we consider the following as possibilities: (1) Inaccurate measurements of NaV1.7 IC50 due to slow binding kinetics. Block develops slowly at concentrations comparable to the IC50 for NaV1.7 and steady-state block may not be attained in the duration of a voltage clamp experiment. However, all three compounds have similar potency in the ligand binding assay. (2) Inaccurate determination of free fraction. In our experience, accurate quantification of free fraction for extensively bound compounds (i.e., when PPB > 99%) is often difficult. High compound lipophilicity and nonspecific binding of compounds may also play a role. Therefore, we cannot rule out that the observed in vivo effects could be correlated to differences of free compound concentrations. (3) Marked differences in free drug concentrations in the dorsal root ganglion (DRG), as has recently been suggested for aryl sulfonamides.(6e) NaV1.7 is highly expressed in the DRG, and inhibition of channel function in this region may be responsible for the analgesic effect. It seems plausible that differences in permeability and possible interactions as transporter substrates may affect nerve penetration, although we were unable to quantify concentrations in mouse DRG. Compound lipophilicity may also play a role. Assuming similar properties for the perineurium and the bloodâbrain barrier, nerve penetration can be inferred from brain exposures, which is lower for 25 (B/P < 0.004) compared to 10 and 13 (B/P > 0.17). (4) Partitioning into the neuronal membrane. Adamantyl triazoles 10 and 13 showed markedly higher lipophilicity than 25, which may lead to increased partitioning of these compounds into neuronal membranes and higher local concentrations in proximity of the binding site. (5) Differences in PK and Cmax. It is possible that efficacy during the testing period (2â3 h after dosing) reflects the time integral of exposure rather than the plasma level only at the time of evaluation of nociceptive effect. The integrated exposure would be more relevant if the residence time of compounds is long, so that binding at Cmax is maintained during the course of the experiment. As demonstrated in separate PK studies in FVB mice (Figure 6C), all three compounds maintained stable plasma concentrations over the time course of the IEM experiments. However, exposure for compound 13 peaked shortly after dosing (at 0.5 h), whereas 10 and 25 reached Cmax 2 h after dosing. We reasoned that this early Cmax, if combined with long residence time, may contribute to the analgesic effect of 13. To test this hypothesis, we determined the association rate constants, kon, by kinetic analysis of binding rates on the Qube platform (see Supporting Information) and then calculated the dissociation rate constants, koff, and residence times. For compound 13, the calculated residence time is >110 min. It is therefore possible that binding at Cmax is maintained during the course of the experiment for 13. However, this scenario does not account for the difference observed for 10 and 25.
    Additional studies on these and other classes of VSD4 binders are ongoing to elucidate the impact of each component on efficacy and will be reported in due course.

    Chemistry

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Benzisoxazoles 4 and 21 were synthesized in four steps starting from 5-chloro-2,4-difluorobenzonitrile (26) as shown in Scheme 1. Coupling of 26 with 1-adamantanemethanol or (3,4-dichlorophenyl)methanol, respectively, provided SNAr adducts 27 and 28. Reaction of these 2-fluorobenzonitriles with N-hydroxyacetamide in the presence of KOt-Bu led to the formation of amino benzisoxazoles 29 and 30. Treatment of the latter with methanesulfonyl chloride and subsequently with sodium hydroxide provided sulfonamides 4 and 21, respectively.
    The synthesis of the triazole sulfonamides initially followed a similar amine sulfonylation strategy. Starting with 3-bromo-4-chloropyridine (31), treatment of the latter with 1-adamantanemethanol afforded SNAr adduct 32. Regioselective chlorination at the 2-position was accomplished by a two-step sequence consisting of N-oxidation with mCPBA followed by POCl3 induced rearrangement to give 2-chloropyridine 33. Displacement of the chlorine by hydrazine provided 2-hydrazinylpyridine 34, which was then converted into amino triazole 35 through treatment with cyanogen bromide. In most cases, the installment of R1 substituents was performed at this stage through a SuzukiâMiyaura coupling with appropriate boronic acids in the presence of Pd(PPh3)4. As such, coupling of 35 with isopropenylboronic acid pinacol ester followed by reduction of the double bond using hydrogen gas and Pd/C provided isopropyl analog 36. Cyclopropyl analog 37 was obtained from coupling of 35 with cyclopropylboronic acid. Reaction of amino triazoles 35â37 with alkyl sulfonyl chlorides followed by treatment with sodium hydroxide then afforded triazole sulfonamides 6, 7, 9â12, and 15. Compound 8 was synthesized in a similar fashion using vinylboronic acid followed by sulfonylation and hydrogenation. Chloro triazole 5 was prepared from 3,4-dichloropyridine following an analogous sequence as shown in Scheme 2. Furthermore, compounds 18 and 19 were obtained via the amine sulfonylation route (see Supporting Information for 5, 8, 18, and 19).
    Isomeric 2-(methylsulfonyl)-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3(2H)-imines such as 38 were often observed as byproducts during the sulfonylation of amino triazole 35â37. Although they were readily separated from the desired products by chromatography, we sought an alternative route for the synthesis of triazole sulfonamides that would avoid the formation of these byproducts. To this end, we envisioned that a Cu-mediated N-heteroarylation of primary sulfonamides with appropriate halogenated triazole precursors might provide a suitable alternative.(24) The required building blocks for this coupling approach were conveniently derived from 2-hydrazinylpyridine 34 in three steps (Scheme 3). Condensation of 34 with triethyl orthoformate to form intermediate 39, ensuing Pd-catalyzed coupling with cyclopropylboronic acid, and subsequent regioselective bromination with NBS provided 3-bromo-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridine 40. With the latter compound in hand, we were set to attempt the coupling with primary sulfonamides. Gratifyingly, heating of 40 with primary sulfonamides in the presence of CuOTf and trans-N,Nâ²-dimethylcyclohexane-1,2-diamine afforded triazole sulfonamides 13 and 14 in 12â78% yield. This coupling protocol was also employed for the synthesis of compounds 16, 17, and 20 from the corresponding precursors (see Supporting Information).
    The synthesis of dichlorophenyl substituted isoxazole 22 proceeded in a similar fashion as described for the cycloalkyl analogs 4 and 21 (Scheme 1and 4). Methyl 4-bromo-2-chloro-5-fluorobenzoate (41) was converted into phenyl benzyl ether 42 in a three-step sequence consisting of ester reduction by LiBH4, sulfonylation of the obtained primary alcohol with methanesulfonyl chloride, and subsequent displacement of the sulfonate leaving group with dichlorophenol. Heating of compound 42 in the presence of CuCN and CuI generated a 2-fluorobenzonitrile, which was converted into amino benzisoxazole 43 by treatment with N-hydroxyacetamide and KOt-Bu. Sulfonylation with methanesulfonyl chloride then afforded isoxazole 22. Compound 23 was obtained via sulfonylation of the corresponding cyclopropyl substituted amino benzisoxazole (see Supporting Information).
    The synthesis of triazoles 24 and 25 started from 5-bromo-2-chloroisonicotinic acid (44) (Scheme 5). Esterification and ensuing reduction of the methyl ester with LiBH4 afforded alcohol 45. Sulfonylation with methanesulfonyl chloride, and subsequent displacement of the sulfonate by 3,4-dichlorophenol or 3,5-dichlorophenol, respectively, generated phenyl benzyl ethers 46 and 47. Displacement of the 2-chloropyridine with hydrazine followed by condensation with triethyl orthoformate afforded benzotriazoles 48 and 49. The cyclopropyl appendage at the 6-position was next installed through a SuzukiâMiyaura coupling, followed by regioselective bromination at the 3-position with NBS to give 3-bromo-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridines 50 and 51. We then employed the same copper-mediated coupling strategy described earlier using methanesulfonamide to obtain triazole sulfonamides 24 and 25.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Two series of highly isoform-selective NaV1.7 inhibitors have been disclosed in the literature, acyl and aryl sulfonamides, which bind to the VSD4 site of NaV1.7. We describe herein the discovery of novel triazole sulfonamides as a third series of selective NaV1.7 inhibitors that are structurally derived from acyl sulfonamides. We hypothesized that the small molecule crystal structure of acyl sulfonamide 1 would resemble the bioactive conformation and applied conformational restraints to validate our hypothesis. This strategy provided potent NaV1.7 inhibitors that bind to the same VSD4 site as acyl and aryl sulfonamides, as supported by ligand binding data. Additionally, SAR and data from site directed mutagenesis provided evidence that triazole and acyl sulfonamides adopt a similar general binding mode within the VSD4 site. Although triazole sulfonamides were generally weaker NaV1.7 inhibitors compared to their acyl counterparts, they markedly improved metabolic stability over the latter series. In particular, compounds 13 (GNE-131) and 25 combined excellent potency with moderate to high in vitro metabolic stability that corresponded to low clearance in mouse, rat, and dog. Despite high plasma protein binding, adamantyl triazole sulfonamide 13 displayed excellent efficacy in a transgenic mouse model of induced pain. In contrast, aryl triazole sulfonamide 25 performed poorly in this pain model, despite showing similar in vitro affinity for NaV1.7 as compound 13.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    General Methods

    Unless otherwise stated, commercially available reagents and solvents were used without purification. Yields were not optimized. Melting points were determined on a BÃ¼chi hot-stage apparatus and are uncorrected. NMR experiments were performed on 300, 500, and 600 MHz spectrometers, respectively. 1H, 19F, and 13C NMR data are reported with chemical shifts (Î´) in parts-per-million (ppm) relative to the residual signal of the deuterated solvent as follows: chemical shift, multiplicity (s = singlet, d = doublet, t = triplet, q = quartet, qn = quintet, m = multiplet, and br = broad), coupling constant in Hz, and number of protons, fluorine, or carbon atoms. Mass spectra were obtained using a Waters 2795/Micromass Quattro LC/MS system (Waters Corporation). Purity was determined by HPLC analysis on Agilent 1100, 1200, or 1260 systems (Agilent Technologies) using a XBridge C-18 column (5 Î¼m, 4.6 mm Ã 50 mm, Waters Corporation) with a 5â95% gradient over 5 min of CH3CN in water containing 0.1% TFA at a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min at 25 Â°C. Peaks were detected at a wavelength of 254 or 280 nm with an Agilent photodiode array detector. All compounds reported herein with biological data exhibited spectral data consistent with their proposed structures and had purities >95% as determined by HPLC, except compound 5 (94% purity) and compound 12 (93% purity), see Supporting Information. Preparative HPLC was performed on Waters HPLC systems using a XBridge Prep C18 column (5 Î¼m, 30 mm Ã 50 mm, Waters Corporation), an XSelect CSH Prep column (5 Î¼m, 30 mm Ã 50 mm, Waters Corporation), or a Gemini-NX C18 column (5 Î¼m, 150 mm Ã 50 mm, Phenomenex) with a 5â95% gradient of CH3CN in water containing 0.1% TFA or formic acid, respectively.

    N-[6-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-5-chloro-1,2-benzoxazol-3-yl]methanesulfonamide (4)

    To a solution of 29 (0.021 g, 0.06 mmol) and triethylamine (0.015 g, 0.14 mmol) in anhydrous CH2Cl2 (1 mL) was added methanesulfonyl chloride (0.008 g, 0.07 mmol) at 0 Â°C. After stirring at ambient temperature for 2 h, the solvent was removed in vacuo, and the residue was dissolved in THF (1 mL) and NaOH (1 M, 0.5 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h, and 1 M HCl was added to adjust pH to 6. The reaction mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate (15 mL) and washed with water (3 mL) and brine (3 mL). The organic phase was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by reverse phase chromatography, eluting with a gradient of 20â50% of acetonitrile in water containing 0.1% NH4HCO3, provided 4 as a colorless solid (0.017 g, 72% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CD3OD) Î´ 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.13 (s, 1H), 3.68 (s, 2H), 3.20 (s, 3H), 2.06 (br s, 3H), 1.86â1.77 (m, 12H), {NH not observed}; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C19H24ClN2O4S [M + H]+ 411.1, found 410.9.

    N-(7-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-6-chloro-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamide (5)

    Compound 5 was synthesized using procedures analogous to those described for compound 7, starting from 3,4-dichloropyridine. See Supporting Information for details. Colorless solid (0.034 g). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) Î´ 8.14 (s, 1H), 6.92 (s, 1H), 3.71 (s, 2H), 2.95 (s, 3H), 2.00â1.95 (m, 3H), 1.76â1.62 (m, 12H), {NH not observed}; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C18H24ClN4O3S [M + H]+ 411.1, found 411.3.

    N-(7-((Adamantan-1-yl)methoxy)-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamide (6)

    Compound 6 was isolated as a byproduct in the synthesis of compound 11 and obtained as an off-white solid (0.018 g, 12% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 7.76 (d, J = 7.7 Hz, 1H), 6.45 (dd, J = 7.7, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 6.36 (d, J = 2.0 Hz, 1H), 3.51 (s, 2H), 3.06 (s, 3H), 2.07â1.97 (m, 3H), 1.80â1.59 (m, 12H), {NH not observed}; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C18H23N4O3S [M â H]â 375.2, found 375.3.

    N-(7-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-6-bromo-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamide (7)

    To a mixture of 35 (0.25 g, 0.66 mmol) and triethylamine (0.28 mL, 2.0 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (13 mL) was added methanesulfonyl chloride (0.08 mL, 1 mmol) dropwise at 0 Â°C. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to ambient temperature and stirred for 0.5 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with CH2Cl2 (50 mL), washed with saturated aqueous ammonium chloride (15 mL) and brine (20 mL), and dried over anhydrous MgSO4. Filtration and concentration of the filtrate in vacuo provided a residue, which was dissolved in THF (2 mL), and 1 M NaOH (1 mL) was added to it. The reaction mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 0.5 h, acidified with 1 M HCl to pH 6, and diluted with EtOAc (80 mL). The mixture was washed with water (20 mL) and brine (20 mL), dried over anhydrous MgSO4, and filtered, and the filtrate was concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by column chromatography eluting with a gradient of 0% to 5% of MeOH in CH2Cl2 afforded 7 as a colorless solid (0.09 g, 29% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) Î´ 13.50 (s, 1H), 8.21 (s, 1H), 6.89 (s, 1H), 3.71 (s, 2H), 2.96 (s, 3H), 2.04â1.96 (m, 3H), 1.78â1.61 (m, 12H); LRMS (ESI) calculated for C18H24BrN4O3S [M + H]+ 455.1, found 455.1.

    N-(7-((Adamantan-1-yl)methoxy)-6-ethyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamide (8)

    Colorless solid (0.005 g). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 8.10 (s, 1H), 7.62 (s, 1H), 6.37 (s, 1H), 3.54 (s, 2H), 3.08 (s, 3H), 2.58 (q, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 2.05 (s, 3H), 1.81â1.66 (m, 12H), 1.25 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H); LRMS (ESI) calculated for C20H29N4O3S [M + H]+ 405.2, found 405.3.

    N-(7-((Adamantan-1-yl)methoxy)-6-cyclobutyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)methanesulfonamide (11)

    To a mixture of 7 (0.19 g, 0.41 mmol), palladium(II) acetate (0.009 g, 0.004 mmol), and dicyclohexyl(2â²,6â²-diisopropoxy-[1,1â²-biphenyl]-2-yl)phosphine (RuPhos, 0.039 g, 0.083 mmol) was added a 0.5 M solution of cyclobutylzinc bromide in THF (4.1 mL, 2.05 mmol). The reaction mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 1 h, then treated with 1 M HCl (5 mL) and diluted with EtOAc (100 mL). The organic phase was washed with brine (5 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo, and the residue was purified by reverse-phase HPLC to afford 6 as first eluting compound and 11 as second eluting compound. Compound 11 was obtained as a beige solid (0.010 g, 6% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3) Î´ 7.57 (s, 1H), 6.33 (s, 1H), 3.66â3.51 (m, 1H), 3.49 (s, 2H), 3.07 (s, 3H), 2.42â2.28 (m, 2H), 2.13â1.99 (m, 7H), 1.82â1.56 (m, 12H); {NH not observed}; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C22H29N4O3S [M â H]â 429.2, found 429.3.

    N-(7-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-6-cyclopropyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]pyridin-3-yl)-1,1-difluoromethanesulfonamide (12)

    To a mixture of 37 (0.34 g, 1.0 mmol) and triethylamine (0.84 mL, 6.0 mmol) in anhydrous THF (5 mL) was added difluoromethanesulfonyl chloride (0.45 g, 3.0 mmol) at 0 Â°C. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to ambient temperature and stirred for 5 h. To the reaction mixture were then added 1 M NaOH (10 mL) and MeOH (2 mL), and the resulting reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h. The reaction mixture was diluted with ethyl acetate (50 mL) and then adjusted to pH 2â3 with 1 M HCl. The organic phase was washed with brine (10 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. Concentration of the filtrate in vacuo and purification of the residue by reverse-phase HPLC afforded 12 as an off-white solid (0.041 g, 9% yield). 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO-d6) Î´ 7.59 (s, 1H), 6.91 (s, 1H), 6.75 (t, JHâF= 53.8 Hz, 1H), 3.74 (s, 2H), 2.05â1.87 (m, 4H), 1.80â1.60 (m, 12H), 0.99â0.90 (m, 2H), 0.74â0.67 (m, 2H), {NH not observed}; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C21H25F2N4O3S [M â H]â 451.2, found 451.3.

    N-(7-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-6-cyclopropyl-[1,2,4]triazolo[4,3-a]-pyridin-3-yl)cyclo-propanesulfonamide (13)

    To a mixture of cyclopropanesulfonamide (1.52 g, 12.5 mmol) in toluene (21 mL) and DMSO (2 mL) was added 40 (4.2 g, 10 mmol) and Cs2CO3 (7.45 g, 22.9 mmol. The suspension was stirred at ambient temperature for 5 min, and then trans-N,Nâ²-dimethylcyclohexane-1,2-diamine (0.44 g, 3.12 mmol) was added. The mixture was carefully degassed with nitrogen, and copper(I) trifluoromethanesulfonate benzene complex (0.74 g, 1.56 mmol) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 10 min and then heated to reflux for 5 h. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to ambient temperature, ammonium hydroxide (40 mL) and toluene (40 mL) were added, and the mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 20 min. The organic phase was separated and diluted with toluene (100 mL). To this solution was added 6% aqueous EDTA (75 mL), and the mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 30 min. The organic layer was separated, diluted with methanol (20 mL), and passed through a short silica column, eluting with 10% methanol in toluene (300 mL). The filtrate was concentrated in vacuo to the point of precipitation. The precipitate was filtered off to afford 13 as a colorless solid (3.90 g, 78% yield). 1H NMR (601 MHz, DMSO-d6) Î´ 13.27 (s, 1H), 7.43 (s, 1H), 6.71 (s, 1H), 3.68 (s, 2H), 2.67â2.61 (m, 1H), 2.01â1.97 (m, 3H), 1.90â1.86 (m, 1H), 1.75â1.70 (m, 3H), 1.66 (s, 9H), 0.99â0.95 (m, 2H), 0.93â0.89 (m, 2H), 0.87â0.82 (m, 2H), 0.68â0.66 (m, 2H); 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d6) Î´ 160.5, 144.1, 124.6, 119.0, 118.0, 89.1, 78.3, 38.8, 36.5, 33.3, 30.8, 27.5, 8.6, 6.0, 4.5; LRMS (ESI) calculated for C23H31N4O3S [M + H]+ 443.2, found 443.2.

    4-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-5-chloro-2-fluorobenzonitrile (27)

    To a solution of 1-adamantanemethanol (0.192 g, 1.16 mmol) in anhydrous DMF (3 mL) was added sodium hydride (0.070 g of a 60% dispersion in mineral oil, 2.32 mmol) at 0 Â°C. After stirring at 0 Â°C for 30 min, a solution of 5-chloro-2,4-difluorobenzonitrile (26; 0.200 g, 1.16 mmol) in anhydrous DMF (1 mL) was added slowly. The reaction mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 6 h, quenched by saturated NH4Cl (10 mL), and extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL Ã 3). The combined organic layers were washed with brine, dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo to afford 27 as a yellowish solid. The residue was used in the next step without further purification. LRMS (ESI) calculated for C18H18ClFNO [M â H]â 318.1, found 318.0.

    6-(Adamantan-1-ylmethoxy)-5-chloro-1,2-benzoxazol-3-amine (29)

    To a mixture of N-hydroxyacetamide (0.036 g, 0.48 mmol) in anhydrous DMF (2 mL) was added potassium tert-butoxide (54 mg, 0.48 mmol). After stirring at ambient temperature for 30 min, 27 (0.050 g, 0.16 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at ambient temperature for 16 h. The reaction mixture was quenched by addition of water (5 mL) and extracted with ethyl acetate (5 mL Ã 3). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous MgSO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo.
